text: hi I'm Michael Cooper from the New York
Times and I'm coming to you from the
Intercontinental Hotel in Miami where
the Republican Governors Association is
reading for their conference these are
not happy days to be a Republican they
just lost the White House by decisive
margin they lost houses in congress and
senate seats and for the first time in
years they're going to find themselves
in the political wilderness and it's
against that backdrop that republicans
were around the country from the state
houses descended here to talk about what
went wrong and what the future of the
party should be many people think that
republican governors are going to
provide the next round of talent and
ideas for the party because you know
Republicans who are left in congress are
going to find themselves in the
opposition which leaves them without
much of a role besides obstructing
trying to stop things and complaining
about things so it's going to be State
House leaders governors who are going to
have to you know carry the party forward
in terms of messages you hear a lot of
different thoughts about what went wrong
in the last election some people here
think that the party needs to return to
its conservative roots be a little bit
more true to its base others are saying
that they think that the party needs to
moderate and you know broaden its appeal
to a wider section of voters you hear a
lot of people concerned about the
demographic trends that are going
against the party people are worried
about this decisive margin by which they
lost the Hispanic load by the fact the
way they lost the african-american vote
the way they lost women votes and so
there's been a lot of sort of
soul-searching going on here but not a
lot of real agreement about what to do
next and against that backdrop there's
still been incredible media scrum around
one particular governor governor Sarah
Palin Alaska CI
I had a baby I did some traveling I very
briefly expanded my wardrobe I made a
few speeches met a few VIPs including
those who really impact Society like
Tina Fey but you saw here every time she
emerged from an elevator there were
cameras flocked or like moths to a flame
there was a much-anticipated news
conference she held on Thursday where
there were about two dozen cameras
present you know scores of reporters and
for all that it wound up lasting about
four minutes and she took four questions
without making much news but there's
still clearly a lot of interest in her
but you know while much of the media
spotlight is on her a lot of other
governors like bobby Jindal of Louisiana
tim Pawlenty of Minnesota Jon Huntsman
of Utah charlie Crist in Florida the
host Governor Mark Sanford North
Carolina are all quietly discussing ways
of bringing the party forward and to try
to recover from what has been a sort of
devastating defeat for them innocent in
essence they're trying to figure out
what to do with their time in the
wilderness so that they can plot a
course back to power I'm Michael Cooper
from the new york times in miami florida
